//notes: Ultradot Pan AV is the source from which multiple companies, including NcSTAR, had copied their no-name sight
personal accounts of comparison say that the original is bad and the copycats are even worse when it comes to red-dot performance
we use the original's dimensions, except for the weight: the lengths are all the same between the different copies, and the weight is manufacturer-dependent
description: A reflex sight largely made popular by video games.  Below-average sighting performance, and abysmal battery life by modern standards.  <sight/installation:picatinny>

variants.description: A reflex sight largely made popular by video games.  Below-average sighting performance, with reports of it holding zero very poorly.  One questionable benefit of it is a variety of emitters, each providing its own reticle pattern.  It has been suggested that all of the emitters running at the same time, even when inactive, contributes to the sight's poor battery life.  <sight/installation:picatinny/embedded_mount>  <variant:black>

//weight: different sources of the same model provide different weights
we use the manufacturer-provided weight of 5.3 oz = 150.25 g
//field_of_view: assumed from a Pinty sight, which is another copy of the original sight
no stats available for the NcSTAR model
the Ultradot original states: 15.7 mm @ 100 m = 0.5397 MOA, which is unlikely to be correct
if it were to be interpreted as 15.7 *meters*, however, at 100 meters it amounts to 8.977° = 538.62 MOA, which is close enough to the other measurement

//lifetime: the manual states battery life to be between 4000 h and 200 h, depending on the chosen brightness
as with other cases, we assume the maximum value

description: A tiny reflex sight.  Often installed on a pistol due to its small footprint.  Requires a special RMR adapter to install.  With an extra adapter, could be mounted onto the military optical sight.

variants.description: A reflex sight popular for its minuscule dimensions.  Its large dot allows for quicker target acquisition, which results in the sight being somewhat less-precise.  Installation requires an adapter for the RMR footprint.  With one such adapter, the sight can be installed on top of an ACOG sight, allowing the user to have two sights at the same time.  <variant:black>

description: A tubular reflex sight, formerly in use by the military.  Its design makes it easier to aim over a single target, though reaiming is hampered.

variants.description: A modern, though still outdated, design of a reflex sight, formerly issued to special forces.  Its tubular design makes it easy to retain aim over a single target due to constrained field of view, the same factor that makes aiming at other targets more difficult.   <variant:black>

notes: neutral trim value is meant to cover attached lens covers and such

description: A large green dot sight in a tubular form factor.  Its construction means a restricted field of view, which makes re-aiming difficult, but helps with accuracy over the current target.  <sight/installation:30mm_single>

variants.description: A large, scope-like tubular sight with a green dot.  Its construction means a restricted field of view, which makes reaiming difficult, but helps with accuracy over the current target.  <sight/installation:30mm_single>  <variant:black>

notes: negative trim value is to account for the adjustment and auxiliary parts that wouldn't (presumably) get covered by taking the largest diameter of the two for the cylinder volume calculations

description: An old design of a sight that had been obsoleted far before the Cataclysm.  Its large form factor, as well as the size and the color of its amber dot, make it stand in contrast with the newer models.  Valued by collectors, though that's unlikely to influence its barter value right now.

variants.description: A legacy design of a reflex sight, rather bulky by today's standards.  The dot is large, at 6.5 MOA, and is colored amber.  While it's been discontinued for several years, it's still sought after by collectors and fans of recent U.S. military history.  <variant:black>

description: A compact, lightweight reflex sight.  This model used to be mounted on the army short-range scope, before a similar model succeeded it as the army's choice.  Despite being an older design, it still boasts comparable performance.  Its large dot makes it easier to aim, though harder to be accurate.

name.str: Noblex Sight II Plus reflex sight

variants.description: A compact, lightweight reflex sight.  The sight of this form factor used to be mounted atop the ACOG as a backup sight for shorter-range engagements.  Noblex, previously known as Docter, was still in business of producing firearm sights before Cataclysm came about.  <variant:black>

A compact, lightweight reflex sight.  This, by some miracle, is an actual Docter MRD: the very same that used to be issued to U.S. special forces in the past.  The sight used to be mounted atop the ACOG as a backup sight for shorter-range engagements.  Despite having nearly-identical dimensions to its younger sibling, this one still clearly says "Docter" -- the previous name of the company -- on the side.  <variant:black>
